moves.10. h3 Bh5 11. g4: White wants to free the N from the pin.
moves.11... Bf7 12. Na4: Be3 is often played. This is an attempt to try something different.
moves.12... Bb6 13. c3 Bxb3: Not clear why Black exchanges now, opening the a file.
White looks for a better square for the N and possible to push the f pawn.
moves.19... Ne7 20. f4: ? But not now. White should first play Nf5.
moves.20... exf4: Of course! White can't retake because of the fork.
moves.21. Bf2 g5 22. Nf3 Ng6 23. Nd4 Ne5 24. N: White does manuever to get to f5, hoping that a slightly more mobile center will offer prospects.
moves.24... Qg6 25. d4 Nf7 26. Qd3 c6 27. c4: White continues a central pawn occupation, hoping for some edge.
moves.27... h5: It would seem now that Black has a strong position, quite possibly better. But...
moves.28. e5: ! This move exploits the position of the Black King.
moves.29... Qxh5 30. e6+: ! This surprising move turns the tables.

opening: two knights defence (C57), Wilkes Barre (Traxler) variation
